(°C) H2 cons. 3DHP 181 443 212 519 228 156 1118 3DIP 180 412 211 442 225 284 1138 3D homogeneous porous copper-ceria catalyst for solar light driven photothermal CO-PROX in H2-rich gas: Enhanced light absorption and abundant oxygen vacancy Xiaolin Guo Conceptualization Supervision Funding acquisition Writing – original draft a b ⁎ Siyi Zhong Formal analysis Data curation Investigation a Wangxiang Ye Formal analysis Data curation Investigation a Ang Zhou Data curation a Zi'ang Chen Data curation a Dingfeng Jin Resources a Qiaoling Kang Resources a Meiqiang Fan Resources a Tingli Ma Supervision a c ⁎ a College of Materials and Chemistry, China Jiliang University, Hangzhou 310018, PR China College of Materials and Chemistry China Jiliang University Hangzhou 310018 PR China aCollege of Materials and Chemistry, China Jiliang University, Hangzhou 310018, PR China b Institute of Catalysis, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310028, PR China Institute of Catalysis Zhejiang University Hangzhou 310028 PR China bInstitute of Catalysis, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310028, PR China c Graduate School of Life Science and Systems Engineering, Kyushu Institute of Technology 2-4 Hibikino, Wakamatsu, Kitakyushu, Japan Graduate School of Life Science and Systems Engineering Kyushu Institute of Technology 2-4 Hibikino Wakamatsu Kitakyushu Japan cGraduate School of Life Science and Systems Engineering, Kyushu Institute of Technology 2-4 Hibikino, Wakamatsu, Kitakyushu, Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Photothermal preferential oxidation of CO (CO-PROX) on copper-ceria catalyst has emerged as an efficient and energy-saving approach for trace CO purification in hydrogen-rich gas. However, the limited light absorption and photo-to-thermal conversion capability of the copper-ceria catalyst hinder its catalytic performance for photothermal CO-PROX. In this study, a three-dimensional homogeneous porous copper-ceria catalyst (3DHP) was developed by using ordered SiO2 microspheres as the hard template. Compared to 3DIP catalyst with disordered silica colloid as the template, the uniform 3D pore structure, smaller particle size and abundant oxygen vacancy in 3DHP remarkably promote its photothermal catalytic performance for CO-PROX driven by the simulated solar light. The uniform 3D pore structure of 3DHP catalyst greatly strengthens the light absorption and photo-to-thermal conversion ability due to the slow photon effect of photonic crystals, which obtained higher surface temperature under the light irradiation. The higher specific surface area contributed to the high dispersion of copper species on 3DHP catalyst. Additionally, the more abundant oxygen vacancy facilitated the activation of O2 and the efficient electron-hole separation in 3DHP catalyst. Moreover, the visible light contributes to the largest portion of the total CO conversion due to the strong absorption ability of 3DHP in this range. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Photothermal catalysis Copper-ceria catalyst Three-dimensional porous framework CO-PROX Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The Polymer Electrolyte Membrane Fuel Cell (PEMFC) is a highly efficient device for utilizing hydrogen energy due to its clean and pollution-free operation, moderate working conditions (around 80 °C), and high energy conversion efficiency. However, the hydrogen produced by catalytic reforming of the organic fuels typically contains small amount of CO, which would poison and deactivate the anode of the fuel cell. The preferential oxidation of CO reaction is a common and effective strategy to eliminate CO in the hydrogen-rich gas and achieve the purpose of purifying H2 [1–3]. Among the catalysts employed for CO-PROX reactions, CuO/CeO2 is a type of promising candidate due to its superior selectivity, activity, stability, and low cost compared to other catalysts such as Au, Pt or Co based catalysts [4–6]. However, traditional thermocatalytic CO-PROX reaction requires external heat sources, which does not fully meet the demands of green energy and hinder the large-scale application of catalysts. Recently, photothermal catalysis, which combines photochemical and thermochemical processes, has attracted lots of attentions in the field of catalysis and is a promising approach to reduce energy demands and achieve a green and low-cost H2 purification process [7–10]. For example, Ma et al. [11] developed a copper-ceria catalyst with well-dispersed photoactive Cu-[O]-Ce species and used it in the preferential oxidation of CO. The catalyst exhibited significantly high efficiency and stable photoactivated catalysis, making it a promising option for practical application in the feed gas treatment of fuel cell supply gas. In our previous work [12], copper-cerium oxide nanorod catalyst was applied to the photothermal CO-PROX, which converts solar energy into thermal energy and further converted it into chemical energy. The copper-cerium nanorod catalyst shows strong light absorption and photothermal conversion ability under simulated sunlight irradiation promotes, which contribute to the high catalytic performance with CO conversion of 90% under 2.5 suns. More recently, an ultrafine ternary CuCoMnOx spinel oxide catalyst was developed using a simple solid phase grinding method, which also delivered high CO conversion for photothermal CO-PROX under 2.5 suns. This was attributed to Cu ions entering into the crystal lattice of CoMnOx spinel oxide and the appropriate calcination temperature [13]. However, the catalytic performance of the aforementioned photothermal catalysts is significantly influenced by the light intensity, which typically requires strong illumination intensities (≥ 2.5 suns) to drive the catalytic reaction. Therefore, it is urgent to further improve the catalytic performance of copper-cerium catalysts through structure and morphology design for photothermal CO-PROX under weak light illumination. In recent years, three-dimensional porous catalysts have gained wide popularity in various catalytic reactions such as soot combustion, catalytic abatement of volatile organic compounds (VOCs), and photocatalytic reduction of CO2 [14]. The physical properties of these materials, such as large pore volume, regular pore structure, and high porosity, contribute to enhanced mass transfer, improved reactant diffusivity, uniform active component loading, and optimal use of active sites. Salvatore et al. [15] prepared Au, Ag supported porous cerium oxide by a template method. The efficient interaction between Au, Ag and the porous substrate makes it excellent in CO-PROX reactions. The high dispersion of the metal on the porous channels of the ceria support further enhances the reducibility of the oxide, which exhibits the highest CO2 selectivity and yield at low temperature (60–100 °C). Liu et al. [16] synthesized a series of macroporous and mesoporous Pt/CeO2 Co3O4 catalysts using PS microspheres as templates. The platinum nanoparticles can be uniformly loaded on the surface of the three-dimensional porous support, which enables the CO conversion rate to reach 92.6%. Xie et al. [17] synthesized Au-supported porous Mn2O3 materials using PMMA as templates. This study shows that the catalytic activity of porous structural materials is significantly better than that of non-porous materials with the same material components. In addition, three-dimensional porous materials are also known as photonic crystals [18]. The special pore structure can prolong the contact time between photons and materials, and store the incident light of a specific wavelength in the three-dimensional porous materials, which can significantly improve the light capture efficiency and extend the light absorption range to the visible light region [19]. Su et al. [20] fabricated a 3DOM CaTiO3 catalyst with a multistage mesoporous perovskite structure. The catalyst has a macro‑meso-microporosity architecture, enhanced light trapping ability, efficient carrier separation and transport ability, which produce a strong synergistic effect to significantly enhance the photocatalytic hydrogen production capacity of 3DOM CQDs-CaTiO3. Li et al. [21] prepared Pt-modified 3DOM SrTiO3 catalysts. Under the combined action of Pt nanoparticles decoration and alkali metal doping, Pt/3DOM-SrTiO3 catalysts showed efficient photocatalytic performance in the reduction of CO2 to CH4. Therefore, engineering three-dimensional porous is considered as an effective approach to enhance the photothermal catalytic performance of the copper-ceria catalyst. Herein, a novel three-dimensional homogeneous porous copper-cerium catalyst (3DHP) was fabricated using the ordered silica microspheres template method and precipitation method. The 3DHP structure provides several advantages, including a large surface area and active sites, making it an ideal catalyst for photothermal CO selective oxidation. The catalyst exhibits exceptional performance in photothermal catalytic CO-PROX, particularly at low light intensity (2 suns). The physical and chemical properties of the catalyst were thoroughly characterized using techniques such as XRD, TEM, N2 adsorption-desorption, XPS, Raman, and H2-TPR. In addition, UV–Vis-IR diffuse reflectance spectra and photoluminescence spectrum (PL) were conducted to determine the optical properties of the samples. Furthermore, comparisons of photo/thermal catalytic performance were explored to distinguish the reaction mode of photothermal catalysis over the copper-ceria catalyst. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials The chemical reagents are of AR analytical grade and do not require further purification before use, and the solutions used are prepared with ultrapure water. Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, citric acid (C6H8O7), ammonia water (20.9%), tetraethyl orthosilicate (C8H20O4Si), NaOH, absolute ethanol and quartz sand were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. 2.2 Synthesis of catalysts The schematic diagrams of the preparation process of 3DHP and 3DIP catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 . 2.2.1 Preparation of ordered SiO2 template A silica colloid solution was prepared through the process of hydrolysis and polycondensation of tetraethyl silicate. The solution was obtained by mixing 50 mL of water, 120 mL of absolute ethanol, and 18 mL of ammonia water to form a uniform mixture. Subsequently, 8 mL of tetraethyl silicate was added dropwise to the mixture with magnetic stirring. After 1 h, a milky white silica colloidal solution was obtained. Next, 100 mL of the colloidal solution was poured into a funnel and filtered for 12 h under vacuum. The resulting material was dried at 80 °C overnight, yielding an ordered SiO2 template. 2.2.2 Preparation of uniform CeO2@SiO2 composite The uniform CeO2@SiO2 composite was prepared by the immersion of the ordered SiO2 template with cerium nitrate hexahydrate precursor solution. Specifically, 10 mmol of cerium nitrate hexahydrate and 2.1 g of citric acid were dissolved in 10 mL of 40% ethanol solution. Then SiO2 ordered template was placed into the precursor solution for 12 h. Then the excess solution was filtered off by vacuum filtration and the template fulfilled with precursor was obtained. After drying at 80 °C, the obtained sample was calcined in a muffle furnace at 500 °C for 2 h to obtain the uniform CeO2@SiO2 composite. For comparison, the nonuniform CeO2@SiO2 composite was prepared by mixing the disordered silica colloid solution and the same precursor solution with continuous stirring for 1 h. The yellow suspension was directly dried at 120 °C and then calcined at 500 °C for 2 h to obtain the nonuniform CeO2@SiO2 composite. 2.2.3 Preparation of porous CeO2 substrate by alkaline etching The obtained uniform/nonuniform CeO2@SiO2 composite oxide was etched by the sodium hydroxide solution of 2 mol/L at 80 °C for 2 h. The obtained yellow precipitate was centrifuged, washed alternately with water and ethanol until neutral, and dried at 80 °C overnight. The porous CeO2 framework with homogeneous pore structure was obtained by alkaline etching the uniform CeO2@SiO2 composite, which was denoted as CeO2–3DHP. And the porous CeO2 framework with inhomogeneous pore structure was obtained by alkaline etching the nonuniform CeO2@SiO2 composite, which was denoted as CeO2–3DIP. 2.2.4 Preparation of CuO/CeO2 catalysts The CuO/CeO2 catalysts were prepared by a precipitation deposition method. 0.2 g porous CeO2 framework was dispersed into 20 mL of 50% ethanol solution and sonicated for 30 min. A certain amount of hydrated copper nitrate (10 wt.% Cu) was added and magnetically stirred for 30 min. Then the sodium hydroxide solution was dropwise added to adjust the pH to 10. After stirring for 10 min, the precipitate was filtrated, washed, dried at 80 °C, and calcined at 500 °C for 2 h to obtain CuO/CeO2 catalysts. The porous CuO/CeO2 framework with homogeneous pore structure was denoted as 3DHP catalyst, and the CuO/CeO2 catalyst with inhomogeneous pore structure was denoted as 3DIP catalyst. 2.3 Characterization methods The morphology and HRTEM were obtained by characterization using a FEI TecnaiG2 F20 transmission electron microscope operating at 200 kV. The elemental distribution was conducted by OXFORD X-max 80T. The structure and phase parameters of the synthesized materials were carried out on SmartLabSE X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku, Japan). The scan range was 10°- 90° with the step size of 0.02. The XPS spectra of the samples were analyzed using Al Kα X-rays on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha+ X-ray photoelectron spectrometer system with a low-power, high-performance data acquisition of 72 W. The analysis chamber was operated at a vacuum level of ≤ 2 × 10−7 mbar, and the energy spectra of each element were calibrated for surface contamination C1s (284.8 eV). Smart model in Avantage software was used as baseline for the fitting of XP spectra. N2 adsorption and desorption isotherm curves were obtained from pretreated samples (treated at 200 °C for 4 h under vacuum) tested on a TriStar II 3020 (Micromeritics Inc.) automated physic-chemical adsorber in a liquid nitrogen environment (−196 °C). The specific surface area of the samples was obtained by the Barrett-Emmett-Teller (BET) formula, while the pore volume and pore size distribution were calculated using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) model. Raman spectra were recorded using a Horiba evolution high-resolution Raman spectrometer equipped with a 532 nm laser excitation in the range of 100–2000 cm−1 for the analysis of the molecular structure of the material. The temperature-programmed hydrogen reduction (H2-TPR) profile was obtained in the homemade device. The sample (50 mg with 60–80 mesh) were placed in quartz U-tube and pre-treated for 30 min at 300 °C under N2 atmosphere. After cooling to room temperature, the atmosphere was switched to 5% H2/Ar mixed gas with the flow rate of 40 mL/min. After the baseline was stabilized, the catalyst was heated from 30 °C to 450 °C at a ramping rate of 10 °C/min), and the change of H2 concentration was detected by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The photoluminescence (PL) spectra were investigated using a Hitachi instrument spectrometer F-7000 with 300 nm laser excitation. The UV–visible diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) of the samples were characterized using a Shimadzu UV3600 UV-visible spectrophotometer at room temperature with BaSO4 as a reference. 2.4 Evaluation of the catalytic performance Schematic diagram of thermal catalysis and photothermal catalysis test system is shown in Fig. S1. Photothermal activity tests were performed in a cylindrical quartz gas-solid reactor. 100 mg of the catalyst was spread evenly on the sand core with a diameter of 40 mm sand. A Xe lamp was utilized as the light source to provide the simulated solar light, and the light intensity is adjusted by changing the distance between the light source and the catalyst. The light composition is changed by using different optical filters. The total flow rate of the feed gas is 100 mL/min and the composition is 25% H2 + 0.5% CO + 0.5% O2, balanced with high purity argon. The exit gas is passed into the gas chromatography to separate and detect the gas composition. O2 is detected by a TCD detector and CO is converted to methane by a reformer and is detected by an FID detector. The CO conversion is calculated by the following Eq. (1) (COin and COout represent the CO concentration in the feed gas and tail gas respectively): (1) C O c o n v e r s i o n = C O i n − C O o u t C O i n × 100 % Oxygen selectivity is calculated by the following Eq. (2) (O2in and O2out represent the CO concentration in the feed gas and tail gas respectively): (2) O 2 s e l e c t i v i t y = 0.5 ( C O i n − C O o u t ) O 2 i n − O 2 o u t × 100 % The thermal catalytic activity test was performed in a quartz tube reactor (φ = 6 mm). 100 mg of the catalyst with 60–80 mesh was placed in the middle of the quartz tube. The thermocouple was utilized to monitor the temperature of the catalyst. The composition of the feed gas and the detection methods of the exit gas were in the same way as the photothermal activity test. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural characterization of the catalysts Fig. 2 presents the TEM images of the copper-cerium catalysts with different pore structures. As shown in Fig. 2(a) and (b), 3DHP prepared with the ordered hard templates exhibits a three-dimensional framework structure composed of connected uniform pores and evenly distributed particle size of ∼ 70 nm. This structure is mainly formed by the agglomeration and nucleation of the precursor that is supported by the ordered SiO2 template (Fig. 2(i)), which maintains the structural skeleton during sintering and etching. As shown in Fig. 2(d) and (e), the 3DIP prepared using non-ordered templates exhibits similar three-dimensional porous morphology. In contrast, large particle stacks of uneven size can be observed on 3DIP, in which the disordered silica microspheres as templates lead to inconsistent cerium oxide nucleation during sintering of the precursor. As shown in Fig. 2(c) and (f), the lattice spacings are about 0.31 nm and 0.19 nm, corresponding to the (111) and (220) crystal plane of CeO2 phase in 3DHP and 3DIP. Moreover, the particle size distribution results (Fig. 2(g) and (h)) demonstrate that the unified particle size of 3DHP is about 70 nm and the uneven particle sizes of 3DHP that distribute among 100∼300 nm. The phase composition and structure parameters of 3DHP and 3DHIP were presented in Fig. 3 (a) and analyzed by XRD Rietveld refinement and the results were present in Fig. 3(b-c) and Table 1 . In Fig. 3(b-c), there are no peaks of silica can be found, indicating that the silica template was completely removed. Both the two catalysts exhibit the diffraction patterns of the cubic fluorite-type structure of CeO2 with Fm-3 m space group. The characteristic peaks of CeO2 in 3DHP sample are much weaker and broader than that of 3DIP, which means lower crystallinity and small basic grain size of 3DHP sample. In addition, the diffraction peaks of bulk phase CuO were observed in the XRD patterns of both samples, and the weight fraction of CeO2 and CuO were calculated by XRD Rietveld refinement. The content of CuO in 3DHP is much smaller than that of 3DIP, indicating the majority copper species are uniformly dispersed in the porous framework of 3DHP while it agglomerates as bulk phase CuO in 3DIP. Moreover, the smaller cell parameter of CeO2 in 3DHP indicates the formation of oxygen vacancy that leads to the shrinking of the CeO2 lattice. The basic grain size was also obtained by the XRD Rietveld refinement. It is obvious that the basic grain size of 3DHP is very small and almost one-third of that of 3DIP, which indicates the ordered SiO2 template can inhibit the growth of CeO2 basic grain and contributes to the higher dispersion of copper species in 3DHP. N2 adsorption and desorption tests were carried out to characterize the pore structure and specific surface area of two samples. From N2 adsorption and desorption isotherm curves in Fig. 3(d), it can be seen that the samples all show the type II isotherm curve of H3 type hysteresis loop, and the hysteresis loop appears in the range of relative pressure (P/P0) of 0.8–1. The adsorption curves in the medium and low-pressure range are close to linear, and the adsorption and desorption curves are close to coincidence, which is a typical manifestation of abundant pore structures. It indicates that the pore structures of the two samples are formed by a large number of macropores and mesopores [22]. And in the high-pressure part, the higher hysteresis ring pressure and smaller hysteresis ring area of 3DHP reveal a larger pore volume than 3DIP. Fig. 3(e) shows the pore size distribution curves of 3DHP and 3DIP. As we can see, the pore volume and pore size distribution of 3DHP and 3DIP are similar, but the pore structure of 3DHP is more concentrated in the macropore range and the pore volume is larger. This is because the nucleation of 3DHP is more uniform than that of 3DIP, forming a large number of intact macroporous structures. The specific surface area, average pore volume and pore size of samples are precisely given in Table 1. Consistent with the XRD analysis, the uniform porous structure and small basic grain of 3DHP make its specific surface area reach 124.9 m2/g and possess larger pore volume of 0.36 cm3/g. The average pore size of 3DHP is smaller than that of 3DIP, which may be caused by the irregular pore structure distribution of 3DIP. The large specific surface area and multi-level skeleton structure of 3DHP are conducive to the adsorption of reactants on the surface of the catalyst, and the larger pore volume is conducive to the rapid diffusion of substances in the catalytic reaction. 3.2 Surface composition and redox properties of the catalysts Fig. 4 (a) shows the Cu 2p spectrum of the sample. Table 2 shows the surface element distribution and valence state distribution of each sample. Among them, the Cu/(Cu+Ce) value of 3DHP is larger, indicating that its surface copper oxide exists in a highly dispersed form on the surface of cerium oxide. The fewer copper species on the surface of 3DIP is due to the agglomeration of copper species as bulk phase CuO, in which the inner copper species could not be detected by XPS. As observed in Fig. 4(a) that the characteristic peaks with the binding energy of 932.9 eV and 934.5 eV are attributed to Cu+ and Cu2+ ions, respectively. As shown in the CuL3vv Auger spectra (Fig. 4(b)), the Auger peak at 917.4 eV is attributed to Cu2+, and the Auger peak at 915.2 eV is attributed to Cu+, the two samples present the consistent peak positions and peak intensity, indicating the uniformity of the porous structure has no distinct effect on the valence distribution of copper species. The Ce 3d spectrum and the peak fitting results of each sample as shown in the Fig. 4(c). The ratio of Ce3+/Ce is obtained according to the ratio of the characteristic peaks corresponding to Ce3+ in the total area of the Ce 3d spectrum, which is listed in the Table 2. Compared with 3DIP, the Ce3+/Ce ratio in 3DHP is higher, it stands for that the uniform and ordered CeO2 nucleation is beneficial to the formation of surface Ce3+ ions, thereby generating more oxygen vacancy. The oxygen vacancy is beneficial to increase the oxygen mobility of the catalyst and conducive to the catalytic oxidation reaction. UV-Raman spectroscopy is sensitive to M-O bond distribution and lattice defects so that scattering spectra with different frequencies from the incident light can be analyzed to obtain information on molecular vibrations, rotation aspects, and oxygen vacancy. UV-Raman was performed to investigate the concentration of oxygen vacancy in 3DHP and 3DIP. As shown in Fig. 4(d), the peak located at 454 cm−1 is attributed to the F2g Raman vibrational mode of the cubic fluorite structure. The peak located at 584 cm−1 is attributed to the non-degenerate LO mode of cerium and is associated with oxygen vacancy in the cerium lattice [23]. The ratio of oxygen vacancy to the characteristic peak area of CeO2 (A584/A454) can be used as an indicator of the concentration of oxygen vacancy in ceria [24]. As listed in Table 2, the values of A584/A454 in 3DHP and 3DIP were 0.42 and 0.39, respectively. This indicates that the oxygen vacancy concentration of 3DHP is higher than that of 3DIP, which is also consistent with the analysis results of XPS and XRD. The H2-TPR test was performed to characterize the redox properties of 3DHP and 3DIP samples. As shown in Fig. 4(e), three reduction peaks of α, β and γ appeared between 150 °C and 250 °C for both 3DHP and 3DIP. The reduction peak of α corresponds to the reduction of highly dispersed CuOx species on the catalyst surface. The reduction peak of β corresponds to the strongly bound Cu-[O x ]-Ce species generated by the copper ions incorporated into the surface ceria lattice [25,26]. The reduction peak of γ corresponds to the reduction of bulk phase copper oxide [27]. The reduction temperatures and hydrogen consumption of the reduction peaks are listed in Table 3 . It can be seen that the reduction temperatures are almost the same for the two catalysts, however, the differences between the two catalysts are that the hydrogen consumptions of peak α and β in 3DHP are much larger, indicating that the formation of more high dispersed copper species and the Cu-[O x ]-Ce species. Moreover, the smaller hydrogen consumption of peak γ in 3DHP also demonstrates the highly dispersion of copper species avoiding agglomerating as bulk phase CuO, which is consistent with the XPS and XRD results. 3.3 Optical properties of catalysts UV–Vis-IR diffuse reflectance spectrum and photoluminescence spectrum were performed to characterize the optical properties of the 3DHP and 3DIP samples. From Fig. 5 (a), it is evident that the absorption of 3DHP in the range of visible light and infrared light is higher than that of 3DIP, except for the intrinsic absorption of cerium oxide (UV band below 400 nm wavelength). This result demonstrates that the three-dimensional uniform porous structure of 3DHP can significantly enhance the visible light and infrared light absorption capacity of the material, which is attributed to the slow photon effect of photonic crystals with anti-opal structure [17]. The values of bandgap energy of the two catalysts are calculated by the Tauc plot (Fig. S2). The band gaps (Eg) for 3DHP and 3DIP were calculated to be approximately 1.63 and 1.78 eV, respectively. This also illustrates three-dimensional homogeneous structure of 3DHP improves the efficiency of the visible and infrared light absorption. The strengthened light absorption endows stronger photothermal conversion ability and higher surface temperature of the 3DHP catalyst under solar light illumination. The photoluminescence spectroscopy was performed to explore the separation efficiency of photogenerated carriers of the samples. As shown in Fig. 5(b), the emission peak around 340 nm is attributed to the charge transition from the Ce4f orbital to the O2p valence band, while the peak around 417 nm is due to the defect between the Ce4f and O2p energy levels. The relatively strongest luminescence peak between 450 nm and 500 nm is attributed to the recombination of electron-hole pairs between surface defects in the CeO2. Ce3+ and oxygen vacancy in CeO2 respectively act as hole traps and electron traps, and as the radiative recombination occurs near the two defect sites, a Stokes-shifted band is shown at 544 nm [28]. Compared with the stronger emission peaks of 3DIP, the luminescence intensity of the 3DHP sample is significantly reduced, which reflects the high separation efficiency of photogenerated carriers in 3DHP. It is attributed to the homogeneous pore structure and uniform small particle size that help the separation of charge carriers and reduce the charge transfer distance, and achieve the inhibition of charge recombination [29]. Moreover, the abundant oxygen vacancy in 3DHP sample captures the photogenerated electrons and transfers the captured electrons to adsorbed species, thus effectively prevents the recombination of charge to improve the photocatalytic activity [30,31]. 3.4 Catalytic performance of the catalysts The photothermal catalytic performance of 3DHP and 3DIP catalysts for CO-PROX were evaluated under the illumination of full-spectra simulated light with an intensity of 200 mW/cm2. As shown in Fig. 6 (a) and (b), the photothermal catalytic performance and temperature of the 3DHP and 3DIP samples are significantly different. Due to the poor absorption of visible light and infrared light of 3DIP, the catalyst surface temperature is quite low (90 °C) and the conversion is only 38%. While 3DHP exhibited higher temperature (100 °C) and more excellent CO conversion efficiency (83%), which is almost twice of 3DIP. It can be seen from Fig. 6(c) clearly that 3DHP has a higher selectivity for O2 compared to 3DIP. The higher surface temperature and superior catalytic activity and selectivity of 3DHP is mainly benefited from the three-dimensional uniform porous structure that strengthens the light absorption capacity and photothermal conversion capacity of the catalyst, while its larger specific surface area promotes the formation of oxygen vacancy and the high dispersion of copper oxide. In addition, we further compared the catalytic performance of 3DHP catalyst with the copper-ceria nanorod catalyst. As reported in our previous work [12], the CO conversion of 10CuCeOx nanorod catalyst is only about 63% for photothermal CO-PROX under the illumination power density of 250 mW·cm−2, which is significantly lower than the 3DHP catalyst in the present work. The 3DHP catalyst shows higher surface temperature of (∼100 °C) than the 10CuCeOx nanorod catalyst (∼80 °C), which mainly caused by the strong light absorption and photo-to-thermal conversion ability of 3DHP catalyst due to the slow photon effect of photonic crystals. Photonic crystal is a kind of periodically ordered microstructure material, which has special regulation of light, and can regulate the propagation of light in the medium and the interaction between light and medium through reflection, scattering and slow photon effect. When the incident light energy falls on the red or blue edge of the photonic band gap, the group velocity of photons will be greatly slowed down, resulting in the "slow photon effect". The slow photon effect prolongs the interaction time between light and matter, which is conducive to greatly improve the efficiency of light capture. Fig. 7 (a) shows the curves of CO conversion as a function of temperature for the samples in thermal CO-PROX reaction. As shown in Fig. 7(a), the low temperature activity of 3DIP is relatively poor with the T90% of 140 °C and the narrow operation temperature window (T99%) at about 150 −160 °C, followed by a sharp decline. This is due to the self-nucleation of a large amount of cerium oxide in the 3DIP porous network with a small specific surface area, which has a detrimental effect on the high dispersion of copper oxide species, resulting in its poor thermal catalytic performance. Compared with 3DIP, 3DHP shows better low-temperature oxidation performance with T90% of 110 °C (30 °C lower than 3DIP) and the broader operation temperature window at about 120 −140 °C. It can be concluded that 3DHP has the stronger low-temperature oxidation ability in thermal catalysis than that of 3DIP, which is benefited from the highly dispersed copper species and abundant oxygen vacancy. The activation energy (Ea) values of 3DHP and 3DIP for thermal CO-PROX were calculated, as shown in Fig. 7(b), which are 19.2 and 36.6 kJ/mol respectively for 3DHP and 3DIP, indicating a lower energy barrier for 3DHP to catalyst the CO molecular reacting with O2. Moreover, the 3DHP in thermal CO-PROX were further compared with the MnCo2O4 catalyst (which is a kind of analogue catalyst for CO-PROX). As reported in the literature [32], the Ea value of MnCo2O4 catalysts is 24.2 KJ⋅mol−1. The Ea value of 3DHP is much lower than the analogue MnCo2O4 catalyst, indicating that the 3DHP is comparable with MnCo2O4 catalyst. To explore the influence of the illumination intensity of the simulated solar light on the photothermal catalytic performance of 3DHP, photothermal catalysis were carried out with different optical power density. Fig. 8 (a) and (b) show the CO conversion rate and the temperature-time curves of 3DHP under the optical power density of 150, 200 and 250 mW/cm2. As the optical power density increases, the CO conversion rate and the catalyst surface temperature were elevated to a certain degree. In order to elucidate the utilization efficiency of photons to chemical energy more intuitively, the apparent activation efficiency of 3DHP at various optical power density were calculated and presented in Fig. 8(c). The apparent photoactivation efficiency provides the efficiency with which the reaction converts optical energy to chemical energy when ΔG < 0. Obviously, the illumination intensity of 200 mW/cm2 makes the catalyst achieve higher apparent activation efficiency (0.59%), however, further increasing the optical power density decreases the apparent activation efficiency, which indicates that excessive photon injection would lead to a decrease in photothermal apparent activation efficiency aggravating the heat loss of the reactor. Therefore, the intensity of 200 mW/cm2 is the optimum light condition for 3DHP in the present experimental condition. In order to study the role of light and heat and the contribution of different light components in photothermal catalysis, several control experiments were also conducted. In Fig. 9 (a) and (b), CO conversion and temperature curves of 3DHP under different light components were given. The xenon lamp is equipped with standard filters and the light source is divided into multiple wavelength ranges. As the illumination intensity of the simulated full-spectrum solar light is 200 mW/cm2, the intensity of ultraviolet band, visible light band and visible-infrared light mixed band are respectively measured as 65, 120 and 135 mW/cm2. Under single visible light irradiation, the surface temperature of 3DHP reaches 78 °C and the corresponding CO conversion is 55%, which contributes to a large portion of the total CO conversion. After adding another 15 mW/cm2 of infrared light, the surface temperature and CO conversion were significantly improved, reaching 83 °C and 61% conversion, respectively. As indicated in the UV–Vis-IR absorption spectrum, 3DHP catalyst possesses the strong absorption capability of the infrared light, therefore, thanks to the efficient photothermal effect of infrared light, a small amount of infrared light provides a large amount of heat energy to the catalyst, which enhances its catalysis ability. In addition, the UV light with the intensity of 65 mW/cm2 delivers the CO conversion of 12%, which is much lower than the visible light with the same illumination intensity, indicating the relatively small contribution of UV light to the total CO conversion and the weak UV light to thermal conversion ability of the 3DHP catalyst. To further compare the catalytic performance of the catalyst under the irradiation of different wavelength bands, the optical power density of the ultraviolet light, infrared light and visible light were all calibrated at 200 mW/cm2 for the photothermal catalytic evaluation. Fig. 10 (a) and (b) respectively present the CO conversion rate and temperature curves of 3DHP under the same optical power density of 200 mW/cm2 with different wavelength bands. The order of catalytic activities and temperatures under different irradiation conditions is Vis (85%, 104.5 °C) > full spectrum (83%, 100 °C) > UV (69%, 91 °C). When the light source is visible light, the CO conversion rate and the temperature reached by the catalyst are further improved compared with full-spectrum illumination. This is caused by the strong absorption of the catalyst in the visible light band. The co-irradiation of visible light and infrared light also showed the same conclusion. However, due to the weak absorption of 3DHP in the ultraviolet light band, the performance under ultraviolet light irradiation is rather low. In addition, a more detailed comparison of the catalytic performance of 3DHP at the same temperature in photothermal catalysis and thermal catalysis was also performed (Fig. 10(c)). Surprisingly, the performance of photothermal catalysis is consistently higher than that of thermal catalysis in the temperature range that can be achieved by photothermal catalysis. This indicates that photocatalysis always provides a certain amount of catalytic contribution when the catalytic reaction occurs on the 3DHP catalyst with three-dimensional porous structure. However, at the higher reaction temperature, the contribution of photocatalysis gradually decreases and the reaction mechanism converts from the photo-thermal synergy catalysis to the photo driven thermal catalysis, which results in the almost identical CO conversion of 3DHP catalyst in the thermal catalysis and photothermal catalysis. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, copper-ceria catalyst with three-dimensional homogeneous porous (3DHP) was successfully prepared by using SiO2 microspheres as the hard template. 3DHP catalyst exhibits superior photothermal catalytic performance for CO-PROX in hydrogen rich streams, as compared with the 3DIP catalyst synthesized by the disordered silica colloid solution as template. The uniform pore structure of 3DHP catalyst enhances the light absorption and its smaller particle size and higher specific surface area contribute to the highly dispersed copper species. Moreover, the higher concentration of oxygen vacancy of 3DHP catalyst benefits the adsorption and activation of oxygen and the efficient electron-hole separation. The 3DHP catalyst achieved a relatively high temperature (100 °C) and a remarkable CO conversion rate (83%) under the illumination of 200 mW/cm2. Meanwhile, the photothermal catalysis mechanism of the copper-ceria catalyst was discussed in detailed investigating the photothermal catalytic performance with different light components and the comparison photo/thermal catalysis activity. The visible light contributes to a large part of the photothermal catalytic activity for CO oxidation compared with the IR and UV light. Moreover, the photocatalysis in the low temperature range (30–90 °C) provided a quantitative contribution to the CO conversion, indicating that the photo enhanced photothermal catalysis occurs in 3DHP catalyst, however, the higher reaction temperature makes the contribution of photocatalysis gradually decrease and the reaction mechanism convert from the photo-thermal synergy catalysis to the photo driven thermal catalysis. coredata.dc:description: Photothermal preferential oxidation of CO (CO-PROX) on copper-ceria catalyst has emerged as an efficient and energy-saving approach for trace CO purification in hydrogen-rich gas. However, the limited light absorption and photo-to-thermal conversion capability of the copper-ceria catalyst hinder its catalytic performance for photothermal CO-PROX. In this study, a three-dimensional homogeneous porous copper-ceria catalyst (3DHP) was developed by using ordered SiO2 microspheres as the hard template. Compared to 3DIP catalyst with disordered silica colloid as the template, the uniform 3D pore structure, smaller particle size and abundant oxygen vacancy in 3DHP remarkably promote its photothermal catalytic performance for CO-PROX driven by the simulated solar light. The uniform 3D pore structure of 3DHP catalyst greatly strengthens the light absorption and photo-to-thermal conversion ability due to the slow photon effect of photonic crystals, which obtained higher surface temperature under the light irradiation. The higher specific surface area contributed to the high dispersion of copper species on 3DHP catalyst. Additionally, the more abundant oxygen vacancy facilitated the activation of O2 and the efficient electron-hole separation in 3DHP catalyst. Moreover, the visible light contributes to the largest portion of the total CO conversion due to the strong absorption ability of 3DHP in this range.
coredata.dc:title: 3D homogeneous porous copper-ceria catalyst for solar light driven photothermal CO-PROX in H2-rich gas: Enhanced light absorption and abundant oxygen vacancy
